comments:
When I'm trying to run code like:

byte[] b = aString.getBytes("Cp850");

and i run this with an internationalized JVM (!) under eclipse i get a

java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException: Cp850

i have found out that it works if i change in eclipse->Windows->Preferences-
>Java->Installed JREs the "JRE system libraries".
i unticked the "Use default system libraries" and added all libraries 
as "external JARs". so that finally not only the JRE system library .../rt.jar 
is there but also .../i18n.jar, plugprov.jar and jaws.jar (i let currently run 
my apps under JVM 1.2.2 11)
Moving to JDT Core for comment

The JAR you added is recorded in a classpath container, but your classpath is 
likely not using this container, but rather a variable with a related name.

You must ensure to use a container on your project classpath (instead of 
JRE_LIB which is only a variable targetting one library, as opposed to 
targetting your container).

You can do so by removing the JRE_LIB entry from your classpath, and adding 
instead a container entry (under advanced action on the library tab).

JDT/UI wants to move away from using variables since containers are more 
powerful.

Is it ok now?

i have tested your suggestion (as far as i understood it). this does not help.
i think you were talking about only changing my application "launch 
configuration".
the only thing that helps is, when i add the jars explicitly to the installed 
jre "JRE system libraries" (preferences->java->installed jre's->edit->jre 
system libraries).

it does not matter if i use the "container" in my classpath or the variable.

No, what I meant is to change the classpath of the project: 
Project>Properties>Java Build Path>Libraries>Advanced>Add Container>JRE System 
Library.

Does this solve your problem?

Then if the container is on the path, and it is missing the i18n.jar, it would 
be a container initializer issue.

Moving to JDT/Launching which owns the initializer.

i am able with your piece of code to reproduce the problem. (by 
just "unticking" the "use default class path" in the launch configuration.)
i do not use the default classpath and in the boot path i have an entry like
(in my launch configuration)

JRE_LIB [JRE_SCR/JRE_SRCROOT]

the problem is *only* solved when i change the definition of the running JRE 
system libraries under eclipse->Windows->Preferences-
>Java->Installed JREs the "JRE system libraries".
when i tick there "use default libraries" it shows only "...rt.jar". and no 
more library. the problem occurs, if i untick the "use default class path" in 
the launch configuration.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 25230 ***
